SUNDAY OBSERVANCE.

A number of years ago, a clergy-
man of the Presbyterian denomina-
tion, who was also a Professor of
Theology, made a startling re-
formation in the church service, by
introducing a pipe organ, instru-
mental music, and processions into
the old church, also preaching
sermons on interesting subjects, thus
making the whole service more ap-
pealing to the public. The result has
been most satisfactory in the reports,
and we are glad to see such a spirit of
reform. Since his death, a complete
change has been made, and now that
we have heard from him, we are
pleased to say that he has done well.

The General Assembly of the Cana-
dian Church has recently issued a
statement calling upon all members
to make their services more attrac-
tive, and to make their sermons more
interesting, so as to attract the atten-
tion of those who do not attend church.

The Sunday School is doing a great
deal of good work, and we hope that
more people will join in this noble
enterprise.

FREEMASONRY.

To the Editor of The Times:

Freemasonry, unlike the
Orange Institution, never seems con-
fined to certain sections or at any time
to disturb the peace and good order
of society, but quietly goes along
with the times, and is always ready
to assist in any emergency.

Perhaps the most eloquent witness
are the Masons in India, who are
working hard to bring about a better
understanding between the different
races.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

Any person who has heretofore been
required to take notice that the
public lands without authority from
the Minister of Agriculture, and
without authority from the Com-
missioner of Dominion Lands for the
District in question, has been sold
without authority is liable to serious
losses and damage, and is advised
not to enter the interior any direct.

For every unregistered quarter
section not having timber on it, or
any application for a homestead on
Dominion Lands purchased a wood lot not exceeding twenty acres in extent, at $5 per acre.

Any person other than a honest
settler who has registered a quarter
section must make application therefore to the
Minister of Agriculture, and must pay
with such application according to law.

Persons who have registered a quarter
section without authority must pay the dues
therefor, and must make application therefor
his office on or before the last May, 1884,
otherwise they will be liable to the penalties
indicated under the Dominion Lands Act.

D. J. WAGGONER,
Crown Tenant Agent.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

CALGARY

From the Herald, June 16.

Last Monday fourteen Indians were present at Okotoks, camping by calling themselves the "Okotoks Band." Mr. Thomas and Mr. Macdonald visited them, and Mr. Thomas administered the oath of allegiance to seven of them. Four of these Indians were present at Okotoks on Friday night, but the others have returned.

Mr. F. Clarke of Toronto, who has been appointed Forest Ranger for this District, in the place of Mr. Swan, previously arrived on Wednesday's train.

A number of Indians from the reserve of Calgary waited on Inspector Steele last Monday evening on the eve of his departure to End of the Road, and purchased some tobacco, also purchasing a cigar and a match receptacle, with other articles. One was bound in money and the other was bound in cheap cloth.

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Gazette, June 15.

The plan of surveying river frontage under the late Surveyor General is still being carried out as being quite pleasant, and it is expected that the Crowsnest herd will show particularly fine specimens.

Mr. R. K. Kennedy has gone to St. Norbert City to begin work on his claim.

Heavy rain fell last Friday night and continued until Saturday afternoon. Tuesday afternoon and evening, heavy showers fell. Also very heavy snow fell yesterday afternoon. A man set out early Thursday morning and paced steadily all day, a regular old fashioned spring rain. Today is clear and fine.

Fort MacLeod parties—quite large—pass frequently through MacLeod, on their way to the south. The weather is very fine for the Colonists, and Mr. D. Coleman, Professor of Geology in Victoria University, is in charge of a party prospecting for a company recently composed of wealthy Winnipeg men.

REGINA.

From the Leader, June 19.

A cricket match between the Government officials and the town will take place next week.

The Local Governor has appointed Joseph C. Irvine, Assistant at Regina, an agent of marriage licences for the town.

A carpenter working on the C.P.R. track in this town, on Tuesday last, was killed by a falling tree. He had been working through the flesh for inches. The Presbyterian Church is to have a new organ installed.

A post has been photographed by Mr. J. A. Brown of Brandon.

On Friday last Regina and Moose Jaw played a friendly cricket match at Moose Jaw.

BATTLEFORD

From the Herald, June 23.

Mr. Wainwright, Inspector of Indians, accompanied by Mr. Macdonald, is making his annual tour of inspection.

Mr. T. Quinn, acting lieutenant at Fort Qu'Appelle, went out in search of a squatter who had deserted the premises of the new agency buildings at the lake. About the 12th inst., the body of an adult male was found near the lake. It was found on the shores of a small lake a little north of the reserve. He had cut his throat and died by the accidental discharge of a gun.

A band of twenty-four muleteers, going for instructions among the new reserve, left Fort Qu'Appelle for the Indian Department stock farm at West River, north of Carlton, which is under the jurisdiction of Mr. Macdonald.

The preliminary survey of the Long Lake Railway, north from Regina, was seen to be begun last week.

FIRST CASE BY EXPRESS.

NEW SPRING AND SUMMER MILLINERY.

STONEWALL.

From the News, June 11.

Prairie wild flowers are abundant in Beaudry district.

A large quantity of cord wood has been gathered for the purpose of timber dues.

The picnic under the auspices of the Transcona branch, held on the Bell farm, Wednesday, was a grand success, a large number of people attending. Several stations were rendered, speeches delivered, etc., quart-pitching was indulged in. Refreshments were plentifully placed with the day's meal. About $80 was raised, which will be used toward repair of the church.

The third sheet of the Government map of Canada, now out includes the west and central section from Lake Superior to the Pacific, including Manitoba and British Columbia, the fourth sheet, is in press.

Mr. Wagner, M.P.P., for Woodlands, started here on Tuesday. He left the same day for the north on a survey.

MINNIPEGOSA.

From the Tribune, June 15.

The heavy rain of last night will be of considerable benefit to the country.

A number of Indians have taken up residence near the town.

The city council have granted $50 towards the celebration on Dominion Day.

An action has been commenced against the Government by Mr. H. G. Henderson, of this town, for returning his land as assigned on trust. Messrs. Smith & Co., are having a valuation set on his lands given them by the Government.

A large field (32 acres) on the east side of the town is now planted with wheat, and looks well.

WINNIPEG.

Free Press, June 18.

About 200 Indians for the mountains arrived from the south last night. They are now camped near the station.

Mr. Walter Newton was struck on Saturday on Main street, and was almost unconscious for a few moments.

A son of Capt. McIlwaine, of the fire department, was killed while fighting a fire.

Mr. and Mrs. Hume have a suit for damages, now before the court, on account of the gun discharged by Mr. Newton.

A boy named Tommy Newton was drowned while bathing in the Assiniboine near Armstrong's Point yesterday.

A portion of the railway at the corner of Market and Main streets caved in yesterday, the result of a washout.

Longest day in the year, also the hottest.

The annual presentation of prizes at Benbow College took place last Thursday afternoon.

Yesterday witnessed the completion of the semi-annual examinations of the pupils of St. Mary's Academy.

ITEMS OF INTEREST

THE VERY LATEST NEWS.

CANADIAN.

Yesterday June 21. The name of Mr. C. Titus was struck off the roll of soldiers at Ogdens Hall on Saturday morning.

A shooting on the Kingston Road this morning attacked a July, twenty-five feet from the house. A man named Wallace went to the lady's rescue and was attacked by the dog, receiving an ugly wound in his right leg.

W. H. Wilson, a drifter from Orangeville, was captured here this morning and returned to Orangeville.

Toronto, June 22. A fire at the City Carriage Works, causing destruction of valuable horses, including the stallion Iron W. B. and the trotting mare Lady Duke.

Mrs. Ramsay, of Guelph, probably the largest woman in Canada, died today. She weighed 500 pounds.

PORT ARTHUR, June 21. A disastrous fire occurred last night, also there, which took place in the morning at Queen's Hotel. The building was entirely destroyed and a number of persons were killed. The guests who had not warning in time enough to escape, with most of their effects, were saved by the efforts of Mr. William Macpherson, traveller to Carcasson & Peck, of Winnipeg, but fire had completely work of destruction. His charred remains were found among the ruins.

MONTREAL, June 22. This morning the chief and valley factory of Sherritt Bros. & Co., St. Hubert, was destroyed by fire. The fire was caused by a spark from a chimney, and the building was destroyed by fire.

GENERAL.

LONDON, June 21. The famous Poveshell, who was arrested for murder, was released from custody today.

NEW YORK, June 22. A young man named Michael, working in the house of Mr. Smith, was killed by a fall from the roof while trying to escape by jumping out of the window.

AMERICAN.

NEW YORK, June 21. A disastrous fire occurred this morning at the wholesale baking house of A. D. Haasen, in Williamsburg. The end of the building was destroyed by fire, and three of these were buried in the ruins. The building was entirely consumed by fire.

Peter McCormick, a wealthy resident of Hunter's Point, was shot and killed by Pat Keenan, one of his tenants, who lives at a liquor store, in a dispute about rent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. Capt. Drake, the schooner C. V. Drake, was destroyed by fire, and the vessel was destroyed by a Spanish gunboat while he was entering the Cardenas Bay. The captain says that the fire was caused by the Spanish vessel, and an explosion occurred shortly after the vessel was loaded with dynamite.

A passenger on the steamer F. J. Deane, June 23. A heavy fall of snow caused the lighting system to fail. The passengers were forced to walk through the streets in search of shelter.
